image.altText: Richard Marles looks up at the camera while speaking at the

props.synopsis: Defence Minister Richard Marles addresses the parliament, revealing as many as nine defence commanders have been stripped of medals following a war crimes investigation

title.children: 'Right a terrible wrong': Defence Minister Richard Marles addresses parliament on war crimes findings

image.altText: An aerial view of a town

props.synopsis: Leaders in Kintore are calling for additional support for their remote Indigenous community amid a spike in young people petrol sniffing and the temporary closure of its only school.

title.children: Teachers evacuated, school closed after 'criminal damage' in remote NT community

image.altText: An older man in a dark suit with a red tie points angrily during a debate.

props.synopsis: Donald Trump couldn't seem to help himself. Almost every red rag that Kamala Harris flashed in front of him, he ran straight for.

title.children: To understand Trump's angry debate performance, you only need to read two lines in his first book

image.altText: A screenshot of a Facebook page titled "Election News".

props.synopsis: Conservative lobby group Advance Australia is dressing old news articles up as new developments and paying Facebook's parent company Meta for the articles to appear in the news feeds of Australians.

title.children: A Facebook page is running a 'malicious malinformation campaign', Meta says it doesn't break the rules

image.altText: Nine CEO Mike Sneesby sitting in the studio

props.synopsis: Nine Entertainment has announced that Mike Sneesby will step down as chief executive, leaving the media company at the end of the month.

title.children: Nine chief executive Mike Sneesby steps down

image.altText: A crowd of people walking around a damaged school.

props.synopsis: The UN Palestinian refugee agency UNRWA has labelled the deaths of six staffers killed in air strikes which hit a school in central Gaza as "just tragic" claiming "no one is safe" on X.

title.children: 'Just tragic': UNRWA laments the deaths of six staffers in air strike on school

image.altText: An aerial view of a beach set at the foot of grassy cliffs

props.synopsis: A new wave of construction is sweeping Bali, carving up rice fields and prime beachfront land for 'Insta-grammable' villas, resorts and massive tourism projects.

title.children: The towering 'eyesore' Bali is building on the 'world's most beautiful beach'

image.altText: A woman runs as police horses move behind her.

props.synopsis: Police are expected to maintain their presence outside the Melbourne Convention and Exhibition Centre today after hundreds of officers clashed with anti-war protesters on Wednesday, resulting in dozens of injuries and arrests.

title.children: Police maintain presence at Melbourne defence expo as human rights groups condemn 'excessive' force

image.altText: An aerial view showing black cattle grazing in a bare paddock near a fallen tree

props.synopsis: Environmental powerhouse, or toothless tiger? Michael Slezak looks at the impact of a proposed federal regulator, in light of how land clearing is managed in Australia.

title.children: Successive Australian governments have done little to stop illegal land clearing. Will a new environmental regulator do the trick?

image.altText: Taylor Swift holds a cat.

props.synopsis: Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump says it was just a "question of time" before pop megastar Taylor Swift backed his Democratic rival, Kamala Harris.

title.children: Trump says Taylor Swift will 'probably pay a price' for backing Harris

image.altText: A tiny lizard sits in a man's hand.

props.synopsis: A new study reveals the scale of Australia wildlife being smuggled overseas, with dozens of species recorded for the first time. But government authorities insist its crackdown is working.

title.children: A growing number of rare Australian animals sold across the globe as new study lays bare 'wild harvest'

image.altText: A bald man with a head tattoo stands between two pacific island men wearing Leis on a street corner/

props.synopsis: While the live music industry used to be in good shape, the pandemic had a massive impact, shuttering venues around the country. A cost of living crisis is also taking a toll.

title.children: The cost of living is taking a toll on Australia's live music venues. A levy could be the answer

image.altText: Clothes hanging on washing lines strung between palm trees above sand.

props.synopsis: A new agreement allowing Tuvaluans to migrate to Australia has come into effect but there are warnings about the challenges that come with such a big move.

title.children: Tuvaluans are preparing for life in Australia as rising tides swallow their country

image.altText: A montage of three images of a three year old boy, with brown hair, smiling.

props.synopsis: Three-year-old William disappeared while playing at his grandmother’s house in Kendall a decade ago. The ABC's Emma Siossian, the mother of a boy almost exactly the same age, was there from the start.

title.children: 10 years since William Tyrrell disappeared, an ABC reporter looks back on his heart-wrenching, unfinished story

image.altText: Tanya Plibersek in a white jacket.

props.synopsis: The federal government's signature nature protection reforms are on the cusp of collapsing, with Labor increasingly ready to walk away if it cannot do a deal with the Coalition.

title.children: Nature protection reforms at edge of collapse, as government readies to walk away without a deal

image.altText: An up close iamge of a moon man award statue

props.synopsis: The 40th MTV Video Music Awards are underway. Follow live.

title.children: Pop stars arrive at 40th MTV Video Music Awards

image.altText: Notre Dame stained glass window showing a napping man.

props.synopsis: Humans didn't always sleep straight through the night, and we didn't always have to deal with a regulated work or school day. Modern culture is responsible for some of the most enduring misconceptions about sleep. Here are seven common myths.

title.children: The key to a good night's sleep? Knowing your body and ignoring these myths

image.altText: ASX in Sydney

props.synopsis: The Australian share market is likely to start its day higher, after Nvidia and other US tech stocks rallied, while traders scaled back their expectations of a significant interest rate cut from the Federal Reserve after some higher-than-expected US inflation data. Follow live.

title.children: ASX to rise following US tech rally, Nine boss quits

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: 'Trump trades' unravel as odds of Kamala Harris presidency improve
The RBA should 'get on its bike' and start cutting interest rates, says former governor Bernie Fraser
Nine CEO Mike Sneesby steps down

image.altText: an upset woman cries out the front of a courthouse

props.synopsis: Brett Andrew Button was behind the wheel of a bus returning from a wedding when it flipped on a roundabout, killing 10 passengers and injuring 25 others.

title.children: Families surprised by bus driver's 32-year sentence for killing their loved ones

image.altText: Writer and Director Josh Margolin's grandmother Thelma on her 104th birthday.

props.synopsis: Inspired by his 104-year-old grandmother’s run-in with phone scammers, writer and director Josh Margolin has flipped the script in a timely reminder of how easy it is to fall prey.

title.children: Scammers demanded $10,000 from Josh's grandmother so he made a movie about her hunting them down

image.altText: Group of women seen from behind, each wearing bright pink singlets or sweat shirts, with caps, and holding running shoe in air.

props.synopsis: After being diagnosed with breast cancer, some people are immediately thrust into having to make a decision about what to do after their breasts are removed. But not everyone is being offered the same choices.

title.children: After mastectomies these women had to choose whether to reconstruct their breasts or remain flat. Here's how they decided

image.altText: A white cup full of coffee sits on a saucer on a bench nest to other coffe-making supplies.

props.synopsis: Your morning cup of coffee could soon get even better, thanks to scientists who have mapped the genome of the arabica plant.

title.children: Better coffee on the cards as researchers crack arabica's genetic code

image.altText: A folder with some documents next to an ABC Radio Brisbane logo

props.synopsis: One of Queensland's largest councils has told the ABC to destroy a leaked spreadsheet and legal letters showing 281 cases of illegal dog regulation.

title.children: Council tries to gag ABC over leaked documents showing unlawful dog regulation

image.altText: A woman wears a dark tracksuit, sits with a baby boy and female toddler. They sit on a playground, cuddling one another.

props.synopsis: Parents and experts say they want to see greater regulation of sugar, additives, and preservatives in pre-made baby food.

title.children: 'Our children deserve better than that': Experts and parents call for better regulation of baby food

image.altText: A womanan uses her phone as she passes a large and illuminated Apple logo

props.synopsis: A tax deal worth billions between Ireland and the maker of iPhones was upheld as illegal by an EU court, meaning an accounting exercise worth $21 billion.

title.children: How Apple paid less than 1 per cent tax in Ireland — and ended up owing billions

image.altText: Walter Sofronoff speaks to media.

props.synopsis: Walter Sofronoff told a News Corp editor that the ACT's former director of public prosecutions Shane Drumgold "wrought evil" and was "eager to lie to jail a man who may be innocent," court documents have revealed.

title.children: 'This is insanity': Court documents reveal texts and emails between Lehrmann inquiry chair and News Corp journalists

image.altText: Aerial view of Big Red Bash festival site

props.synopsis: The Big Red Bash, which injects millions of dollars into the western Queensland economy, has been cancelled for 2025 with organisers saying they are "taking a breather".

title.children: Australia's most remote music festival cancelled next year with organisers 'overdue a break'

image.altText: A white and purple building with a sign for 'GISB HOLDINGS' on the front

props.synopsis: More than 1,000 police conducted the raids on 20 welfare homes, resulting in 171 arrests.

title.children: More than 400 minors suspected of being abused rescued by Malaysian authorities in mass raids

image.altText: Mitch Marsh

props.synopsis: Australian batting star Travis Head reaches his 50 in just 19 balls before Australia's bowlers finish off the job to beat England in their first T20 of the series.

title.children: Head smashes an Australian T20 record as England crumbles in run chase at Southampton

image.altText: A man pushes a stack of plyboards in flood following a typhoon.

props.synopsis: The death toll in Vietnam from Asia's worst storm this year reaches 152, with torrents of rain triggering floods and landslides, burying homes, sweeping away a bridge and now threatening the capital Hanoi.

title.children: Typhoon Yagi unleashes destruction in Vietnam, kills at least 152

image.altText: A man in the suit on the left looks happy with himself and a man in the right in a suit looks up up at the gallery

props.synopsis: The Tasmanian Liberal government will release its 11th consecutive state budget today, with debt levels projected to rise to $8.5 billion in four years' time. The premier says it is not the time to reduce investment in 'key areas'.

title.children: Record debt levels will be outlined in Tasmanian budget, but the premier says it shows a 'sensible' path to surplus

image.altText: Close-up of a sad-looking woman talking on smartphone in a dark space.

props.synopsis: Family dynamics can be complicated and going 'no contact' to avoid further conflict is often suggested on social media. Here's what the phrase means and why it's surging online.

title.children: What drives people to cut contact with family members
